headline: Grandma's Zucchini Cake
description: My grandmother's recipe for a gently spicy sheet cake, made with freshly grated zucchini.
name: Grandma's Zucchini Cake
keywords: Baking, Cake, Sheet Cake, Zucchini, American, Dessert
recipeIngredient: 2 teaspoons cinnamon (can sub 1 teaspoon with other spices such as allspice and nutmeg, go easy on the cloves though)
1 teaspoon grated lemon zest (optional, my addition)
2 cups (from about 3-4 regular sized zucchini) grated un-peeled zucchini (place grated zucchini in a sieve and press out some of the excess moisture before measuring)
1 cup chopped walnuts or pecans (my grandmother recommends black walnuts)
3 ounces cream cheese, softened to room temperature (Philadelphia cream cheese recommended)

recipeInstructions.text: Preheat oven to 350Â°F. Butter a 9x12 or 9x13 baking pan (I used a pyrex pan).
Whisk the dry cake ingredients together: In a medium bowl, whisk together the flour, cinnamon, baking soda, salt, and baking powder. Set aside.

Add the remaining cake ingredients: Beat in the wet eggs, sugar, oil, vanilla, and zest then stir In a mixer, beat the 3 eggs on high speed until frothy. Lower the speed and beat in the sugar, vegetable oil, vanilla, and lemon zest (if using). Stir in the flour mixture, a third at a time. Stir in the zucchini and chopped nuts and/or raisins.

Pour into baking pan and bake: Pour mixture into a 9x12 or 9x13 baking pan. Bake at 350Â°F for 40 to 45 minutes. (My grandmother's notes say you can also bake in an angel food pan for 1 hour.) Remove from oven and let cool completely before frosting. (While the cake is cooling, let the frosting's cream cheese and butter sit at room temperature to soften.)

Make the frosting and frost the cooled cake: To make the frosting, beat together the cream cheese and butter. Add the powdered sugar and beat until smooth. Frost the cake and serve. Store covered with aluminum foil. It's so eerie to look at my grandmother's notes. She mentions that "black walnuts are good". Black walnuts are pretty hard to find, but there was a black walnut tree on our block that she and I would pass on the way to the grocery store. If there were any nuts on the ground, she would gather them and we would crack them open with a hammer when we got home. Her hand got shakier as she got older. By her 90s she had the symptoms of Parkinson's. There's a more recent note to my sister advising her to drain the zucchini, where her handwriting is noticeably more wobbly.

review.reviewBody: Made this for my dad who can't have carrot cake. It was a huge success. Instead of Frosting I put some brown sugar, water, cinnamon and cloves in a saucepan and reducing it to almost a syrup and poured that over the top. Then sprinkled with more brown sugar.

I LOVE this cake ( I did the angel food pan)! Iâ€™m not one for chocolate so this is perfect! Iâ€™ve made it twice since I found the recipe and Iâ€™m making it again now for friends. I did make a few changes to cut down on the calories but the recipe handled it well. Thanks so much for posting this!
I made this last year for my son's birthday and my wife bought one from the grocery store, my son asked me to make this one for this birthday
Waaay too sweet. I think the sugar amount could be cut in half and it would still be a sweet cake. I follow the recipe exactly as written

Thank you for your Grandmaâ€™s recipe!! ðŸ¤— This is the best recipe for zucchini cake I have ever made! I use only one cup of sugar in the batter and it is plenty sweet enough! I grate a zucchini by hand and place it in a sieve to press out the excess water! Take a mug and press down on the zucchini in the sieve. I press out more zucchini water in between paper towels. This recipe never fails if your ingredients are fresh!!ðŸ˜‹
